definition:
If $f : X\to Y$ is a continuous map of topological spaces, and if
${\bf Sheaves}(X)$ is the category of sheaves of abelian groups on $X$
(and similarly for ${\bf Sheaves}(Y)$), then the direct image functor
$f_* : {\bf Sheaves}(X)\to {\bf Sheaves}(Y)$ sends a sheaf $\mathcal{F}$
on $X$ to its direct image $f_*\mathcal{F}$ on $Y$. A morphism of
sheaves $g : \mathcal{F}\to\mathcal{G}$ obviously gives rise to a
morphism of sheaves $f_* g : f_*\mathcal{F}\to f_*\mathcal{G}$, and this
determines a functor.

If $\mathcal{F}$ is a sheaf of abelian groups (or anything else), so is
$f_*\mathcal{F}$, so likewise we get direct image functors
$f_* : {\bf Ab}(X)\to {\bf Ab}(Y)$, where ${\bf Ab}(X)$ is the category
of sheaves of abelian groups on $X$.
